 One thing I find interesting, and somewhat disturbing, is that people tend to identify an individual as either heterosexual or homosexual based on their sexual activity. For me, and many other homosexual people that I know personally, this "sexual activity" is only one of many aspects that is part of who and what we are. The relationship I share with my husband (yes, we consider ourselves that, be it legal or otherwise) is in no way based solely on sexual activity. It is based on love, trust, compassion, commitment, and truly caring about each other. Any sexual activity is merely an outgrowth of these feelings. To us, it is sharing this depth of feeling with a person of the same gender that makes us homosexuals, not just some sex act we may or may not perform in the privacy of our bedroom. 
 
 I ran across this in a novel I am currently reading:
 
 

 Courage
 
 
 Why is it that people think bravery is either leaping into a fight or running away from everything that comforts them? The most courageous act a human being can perform is to truly love another person.
 
 There are those who would have us believe that love is easy. that it comes childlike from our hearts and floods out as effortlessly as rain falls from the fingers of the sky.
 
 That is just foolishness.
 
 Love is standing guard all the time. It is becoming a world into yourself for another's sake, and learning to share it's most intimate corners. There is nothing more courageous than that. And nothing more achingly beautiful.
